title: 111_hr5780
content: The Act titled "Reduce and End our Deficits Using Commonsense Eliminations in the Energy Program Act of 2010" terminates payments to certified states and Indian tribes under the Abandoned Mine Lands Program as per amendments to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977. The Secretary certifies completion of reclamation projects for eligible land and water. Public comment is allowed on certifications. Payments to certified states and tribes are limited, except for health benefits. Payments for health benefits under subsections (h) and (i) of section 402 are not affected by the certification of completion of reclamation projects for eligible land and water. SEC. 3. TERMINATE OIL AND GAS COMPANY TAX PREFERENCES. Repeal of various tax preferences for oil and gas companies, including the Enhanced Oil Recovery Credit, Credit for Oil and Gas Produced From Marginal Wells, Expensing of Intangible Drilling Costs, and Deduction for Tertiary Injectants after specific dates mentioned in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Repeal of tax preferences for oil and gas companies, including deductions for tertiary injectants, passive loss limitation exceptions, and percentage depletion for oil and gas wells after specific dates mentioned in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Repeal of tax preferences for oil and gas companies, including deductions for tertiary injectants, passive loss limitation exceptions, and percentage depletion for oil and gas wells after specific dates mentioned in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments made to sections of the Code regarding domestic manufacturing tax deduction, production or extraction related to oil or gas, and geological and geophysical amortization period for independent producers extended to seven years. Amendments to section 167(h) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 change the 24-month period to a 7-year period. Effective dates for the amendments vary depending on the subsections, with some applying to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 is being amended to repeal sections related to oil and gas research and development. The Secretary of Energy is instructed to stop the application for a nuclear waste repository at Yucca Mountain, Nevada. Additionally, certain SEPA and TVA facilities are to be sold. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 is being amended to repeal sections related to oil and gas research and development. The Secretary of Energy is instructed to stop the application for a nuclear waste repository at Yucca Mountain, Nevada. Sale of Southeastern Power Administration and TVA Facilities is also planned, including the sale of electric energy generation facilities owned by Federal departments under the Southeastern Power Administration. The Secretary of Energy will implement sales of electric energy generation facilities, excluding dams and reservoirs. A report must be submitted to Congress before implementing any plan. The Tennessee Valley Authority facilities will also be included in the sale program. The Tennessee Valley Authority will develop a plan to sell its electric power program, excluding hydroelectric facilities. A report must be submitted to Congress before implementing the plan, and the proceeds from the sale will be used accordingly. The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to sell its electric power program, excluding hydroelectric facilities. Proceeds from the sale will first cover sale costs, then repay outstanding debt to the United States. Any excess proceeds will go to the Treasury as miscellaneous receipts. The sale is not considered disposal of Federal surplus property. Sales should be completed by December 31, 2010, and the Southeastern Power Administration will be terminated. Following the sale of assets, the Secretary of Energy will close out the Southeastern Power Administration and return any remaining funds to the Treasury of the United States. The Energy Policy and Conservation Act is amended to reduce the volume of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve from 1 billion to 650,000,000. Additionally, sections related to ultra-deepwater and unconventional natural gas resources in the Energy Policy Act of 2005 are repealed.
